citation.excerpt:
If you use this code for your research, please consider citing our [paper](https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/2041-8213/abc255). ([arXiv preprint](https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.07553)) @article{jeong2020solar, title={Solar coronal magnetic field extrapolation from synchronic data with AI-generated farside}, author={Jeong, Hyun-Jin and Moon, Yong-Jae and Park, Eunsu and Lee, Harim}, journal={The Astrophysical Journal Letters}, volume={903}, number={2}, pages={L25}, year={2020}, publisher={IOP Publishing} }
* Correction in our paper:
1) We trained our model with 3412 pairs of training dataset for 630,000 iterations (∼180 epochs).
The number of epoch was 180, not 150. It is a hyperparameter that defines the number times that the deep learning model works through the entire training dataset.
(the number of epoch) = (iterations) / (the number of dataset). 2) We used [LSGAN](https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.04076) loss instead of cGAN loss in our deep learning model. _____________
* Total loss = ( LSGAN loss ) + 10 * ( Feature Matching loss )

description.excerpt:
Solar farside magnetograms are generated by the Pix2PixHD model.     
We train and evaluate the model using pairs of SDO/AIA EUV passband images and SDO/HMI magnetograms.
The Pix2PixHD is based on conditional Generative Adversarial Networks (cGANs) framework, which is one of the popular deep learning methods for image translation.

The model consists of two major networks:  
 one is a generative network (generator) and the other is a discriminative network (discriminator).
which one is a more real-like pair between a real pair and a fake pair.

In our model, we use a global generator (G). 
The generator is consist of the Encoder - Residual Blocks - Decoder.
One discriminator gets input pairs of the original pixel size, and the other gets input pairs which are downsampled by half.
The Loss configuration of the Objective functions

installation.excerpt: This code has been tested on Ubuntu 18.04 with a Nvidia GeForce GTX Titan XP GPU, CUDA Version 11.0, Python 3.6.9, and PyTorch 1.3.1.
